title: 104_hr125
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gun Crime Enforcement and Second Amendment Restoration Act of 1996". The Congress finds that protecting citizens from armed violent criminals is crucial for public safety and prosperity. Banning specific firearms does not deter criminals, so the focus should be on arresting, convicting, and incarcerating them effectively. The Attorney General must establish an armed violent criminal apprehension program within 180 days of this Act. Each US attorney must appoint a prosecutor and create a task force to remove armed violent criminals from the streets. The program should focus on severe punishment to deter crime and consider both federal and state laws. The Attorney General must establish a program to remove armed violent criminals from the streets, considering the importance of severe punishment, effectiveness of laws, resources available to law enforcement agencies, nature of violent crime in the district, and limited Federal involvement in prosecution. The program should be implemented not less frequently than monthly. The Attorney General requires United States attorneys to report monthly on defendants charged with violating specific sections of the law. Biannually, a compilation of this information and waivers granted must be submitted to Congress. The Attorney General appoints a United States attorney who must report monthly on defendants charged with specific violations. Biannually, a compilation of this information and waivers granted must be submitted to Congress. United States attorneys can request waivers from the Attorney General for reporting requirements. The Attorney General can grant waivers based on established guidelines, considering the number of assistant United States attorneys in the office. The Attorney General establishes guidelines for reporting requirements requested by United States attorneys, considering the number of assistant attorneys and level of violent crime. An "armed violent criminal" is defined as someone accused of specific firearm violations after a previous violent crime conviction. This section expires after five years from enactment. The term "armed violent criminal" refers to a person accused of violating specific firearm laws after a previous conviction for a violent crime. This section will expire five years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPEAL OF THE PROHIBITIONS RELATING TO SEMIAUTOMATIC ASSAULT WEAPONS AND LARGE CAPACITY AMMUNITION FEEDING DEVICES. This section amends various sections of the United States Code to repeal prohibitions on certain firearms and ammunition feeding devices. MANDATORY PRISON TERMS for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm or destructive device during a federal crime that is a crime of violence or a drug trafficking crime. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory prison terms for possessing or brandishing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking crime. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, while brandishing leads to 10 years imprisonment. The amended Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing leads to 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure results in 20 years. Additional sentences apply for specific types of firearms. The amended Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code mandates prison terms for possessing, brandishing, or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Possession results in 5 years imprisonment, brandishing leads to 10 years, and discharging with intent to injure results in 20 years. Additional sentences apply for specific types of firearms, with varying imprisonment terms ranging from 10 to 30 years depending on the type of firearm involved. Subsequent convictions result in a minimum of 20 years imprisonment if a firearm is possessed during the crime. If a person possessed, brandished, or discharged a firearm during a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking, they face additional imprisonment terms of not less than 20, 25, or 20 years respectively. If a person discharged a firearm with the intent to injure during a second or subsequent crime of violence or drug trafficking, they face imprisonment for not less than 30 years. Life imprisonment is mandated if the firearm is a machinegun, destructive device, or equipped with a silencer or muffler. Probationary sentences are not allowed for violations of this subsection. The court shall not impose probation or concurrent imprisonment for a person convicted of using a firearm in a second offense, mandating life imprisonment. No release is allowed during the imposed term of imprisonment. Passed the House of Representatives on March 22, 1996. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
